Posts.Content: May 8, 2013 02:19AM GainesvilleSpouse wrote: Thank you for the responses. She had a mammogram and ultrasound this morning with a new doctor who is very experienced - tens of thousands of patients over 30+ years. She spent a lot of time with us. Went over both the ultrasound and mammogram images very carefully. Didn't seem to see anything beyond the nipple area. Used the ultrasound on the lymph nodes and seemed to think they were clear. We felt my wife's symptoms suggested Paget's Disease, a rare form of breast cancer. Happily (since that is often more aggressive) the doctor felt that was unlikely. Then an MRI this afternoon. And she sees the surgeon tomorrow - who will have all this info. (We also really liked the oncologist whom we saw last Thursday - who will be in charge of any radiation or chemo that is needed post-op.) Technology today is amazing. The doctor this morning had obtained, via computer apparently, my wife's mammogram images from her annual exams over the past several years. She brought them up side by side on a big screen to compare changes over the years. We are both tired - especially, I think, from the recent days' anxiety - but were encouraged by this morning's meeting. And by something as simple as the doctor setting up an appointment to see her again in nine months for another mammogram.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2013 02:40PM GainesvilleSpouse wrote: Since my last post it has been a bit of a rollercoaster, but Mondat and yesterday were "okay" - mostly just mild queasiness - and today she woke up feeling pretty normal. We are still trying to figure things out. Will this be her normal cycle after chemo - several rollercoaster days, some miserable - followed by a good spell? Or to what extent did Phenergan relieve her GI discomfort and resultant nausea? Time will tell. But far more encouraging than the daunting prospect of four and a half months of non-stop bad days. Fingers crossed.
